item.title: Complete Guide to Claude Code Skills
item.description:
Personal study notes

Chapter 1: What are Skills

1.1 Introduction to Skills

Skills are an extension system for Claude Code, similar to installing “skill packs” for Claude.

Simple Understanding:

  • Like mobile apps: you can install different apps on your phone to achieve different functions
  • Skills are “functional plugins” installed for Claude
  • Each Skill teaches Claude a new capability

Examples:

  • Install docx skill ‚Üí Claude can create and edit Word documents
  • Install pdf skill ‚Üí Claude can process PDF files
  • Install mysql-manager skill ‚Üí Claude can operate databases

1.2 Types of Skills

Official Skills (Provided by Anthropic)

  • Developed and maintained by Claude’s official team
  • Guaranteed quality and stable functionality
  • Free to use
  • Examples: docx, pdf, pptx, xlsx, etc.

Community Skills (Third-party Development)

  • Contributed by community developers
  • Diverse functionalities
  • Quality needs to be evaluated independently

Custom Skills (Created by You)

  • Customized according to your needs
  • Fully controllable
  • This tutorial will teach you how to create them

1.3 Why Use Skills

Without Skills:

You: Help me create a Word document
Claude: Sorry, I cannot directly create Word documents

With Skills:

You: Help me create a Word document
Claude: OK! (Automatically uses docx skill to create document)

Advantages of Skills:

  1. ‚úÖ Extend Claude’s capabilities
  2. ‚úÖ Automate repetitive tasks
  3. ‚úÖ Improve work efficiency
  4. ‚úÖ Can customize exclusive functions

1.4 How Skills Work 

Your request ‚Üí Claude analyzes ‚Üí Select appropriate Skill ‚Üí Execute operation ‚Üí Return results

Example Process:

  1. You say: “Create a Word document”
  2. Claude identifies that document processing is needed
  3. Claude calls the docx skill
  4. docx skill executes document creation code
  5. Returns the created document

Chapter 2: Environment Preparation

2.1 Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have installed:

Required Software

1. Claude Code CLI

  • This is Claude’s command-line tool
  • If you can run Claude Code, it means you’ve already installed it
  • Check method: 
    claude --version

2. Node.js (Required for some skills)

  • Version requirement: 14.0 or higher
  • Check installation: 
    node --version
npm --version
  • If not installed, visit: https://nodejs.org/
  • Download LTS (Long Term Support) version

3. Git (Optional, for cloning official repository)

  • Check installation: 
    git --version
  • If not installed, visit: https://git-scm.com/

2.2 Understanding File Locations

Important Directory Structure:

Your user directory/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .claude/ # Claude configuration directory
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ skills/ # Custom skills storage location
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ mysql-manager/ # Example: custom skill
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ SKILL.md # Skill definition file
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ config.json # Configuration file
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mysql-tool.js # Tool script
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md # Documentation
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ plugins/ # Plugins directory
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ marketplaces/ # Skills marketplace
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ anthropic-agent-skills/
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ skills/ # Official skills

‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ pdf/
‚îÇ ‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ ...
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ config.json # Global configuration file

Paths on Different Operating Systems:

Windows:

  • User directory: C:\Users\YourUsername\
  • Claude directory: C:\Users\YourUsername\.claude\
  • View method: 
    echo %USERPROFILE%\.claude

Mac:

  • User directory: /Users/YourUsername/
  • Claude directory: /Users/YourUsername/.claude/
  • View method: 
    echo ~/.claude

Linux:

  • User directory: /home/YourUsername/
  • Claude directory: /home/YourUsername/.claude/
  • View method: 
    echo ~/.claude

2.3 Environment Check

Step 1: Check Claude Code

claude --version

Expected output: Shows version number

Step 2: Check Node.js

node --version
npm --version

Expected output: Shows version number (e.g., v20.9.0)

Step 3: Check Configuration Directory

# Windows
dir %USERPROFILE%\.claude

# Mac/Linux
ls -la ~/.claude

Expected output: Shows .claude directory contents

Chapter 3: Installing Official Skills

3.1 Adding Official Skills Marketplace

Step 1: Start Claude Code

In terminal or command line:

claude-code

Step 2: Add Official Marketplace

In Claude Code, enter:

/plugin marketplace add anthropics/skills

Expected Result:

Successfully added marketplace: anthropic-agent-skills

What did this do?

  • Connected to Anthropic’s official skills repository (GitHub)
  • Downloaded skills list to your computer
  • Storage location: ~/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/anthropic-agent-skills/
  • But hasn’t installed specific skills yet

What if it fails?

  • Check network connection
  • Ensure GitHub access
  • Try using proxy (if in China)

3.2 Browsing Available Skills

Method 1: Browse via Command

/plugin browse

Method 2: View Downloaded Skills

# Windows
dir %USERPROFILE%\.claude\plugins\marketplaces\anthropic-agent-skills\skills

# Mac/Linux
ls ~/.claude/plugins/marketplaces/anthropic-agent-skills/skills/

Available Skills:

Skill Name Function Description Use Cases
docx Word document processing Create reports, edit documents
pdf PDF file processing Extract text, merge PDFs
pptx PowerPoint presentations Create slides
xlsx Excel spreadsheets Data processing, table creation
frontend-design Frontend design Web design, UI components
algorithmic-art Algorithmic art Generate art, animations
canvas-design Canvas design Posters, graphic design
mcp-builder MCP servers API integration
webapp-testing Web testing Automated testing
skill-creator Skill creation Create custom skills
More… … …

3.3 Installing Skills

Method 1: Install Example Skills Package (Recommended for Beginners) 

/plugin install example-skills@anthropic-agent-skills

This command will install:

  • All example skills (16 total)
  • Including document processing, design, development, etc.
  • Suitable for learning and daily use

Expected Result:

‚úì Installed example-skills. Restart Claude Code to load new plugins.

Method 2: Install Document Skills Package

If you only need document processing functions:

/plugin install document-skills@anthropic-agent-skills

This command will install:

  • docx (Word)
  • pdf (PDF)
  • pptx (PowerPoint)
  • xlsx (Excel)

Method 3: Install Single Skill (Advanced) 

/plugin install docx@anthropic-agent-skills

3.4 Restart Claude Code

Important: Must restart Claude Code after installation for changes to take effect!

Steps:

  1. Exit current Claude Code session

    • Enter exit or
    • Press Ctrl+C (Windows/Linux) or Cmd+C (Mac)

  2. Restart:

    claude-code

3.5 Verify Installation

Method 1: Ask Claude

In Claude Code, enter:

What skills do you have?
List all available skills

Claude will list all installed skills.

Method 2: Test a Skill 

Help me create a test Word document

If Claude successfully creates the document, skills installation succeeded!

Method 3: View System Information 

# View installed skills
ls ~/.claude/plugins/cache/

Chapter 4: Using Skills

4.1 Three Ways to Use Skills

Method 1: Natural Language (Recommended for Beginners)

Directly describe your needs in everyday language, Claude will automatically select the appropriate skill.

Examples:

Create a Word document
Process this PDF file
Design a login page
Query database

Advantages:

  • Simplest, no need to remember skill names
  • Claude automatically determines which skill to use
  • Suitable for daily use

Disadvantages:

  • Sometimes Claude might choose the wrong skill
  • Not precise enough

Method 2: Explicitly Specify Skill

If you know which skill to use, you can specify it explicitly.

Examples:

Use docx skill to create report
Use pdf skill to extract text
Use mysql-manager to query data

Advantages:

  • More precise
  • Avoids Claude choosing wrong skill
  • Suitable for repetitive tasks

Disadvantages:

  • Need to remember skill names

Method 3: Direct Command Call (Advanced Users)

For custom skills, can call commands directly.

Examples:

cd ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager
node mysql-tool.js list-databases

Advantages:

  • Fastest
  • Full control
  • Suitable for scripting

Disadvantages:

  • Need command-line knowledge
  • Need to know specific commands

4.2 Common Skills Usage Examples

üìÑ Document Processing Skills

Create Word Document (docx):

Basic usage:

Create a Word document

Detailed usage:

Create a project report document, including:
- Title: 2024 Annual Summary
- Subtitle: Technical Department
- Three chapters: Background, Implementation, Results

Save as report.docx

Process PDF (pdf):

Extract text:

Extract all text from report.pdf

Merge PDFs:

Merge file1.pdf and file2.pdf into merged.pdf

Split PDF:

Extract pages 1-5 from document.pdf as new file

Create PowerPoint (pptx):

Create a product introduction presentation, including:
- Cover page
- Product features (3 pages)
- Pricing plan (1 page)
- Contact information (1 page)

Process Excel (xlsx):

Create a sales data spreadsheet, including:
- Columns: Date, Product, Quantity, Amount
- 10 rows of test data
- Add sum formulas

üé® Design Skills

Frontend Design (frontend-design):

Login page:

Design a modern-style login page, including:
- Username and password input fields
- Remember me option
- Login button
- Blue theme

Navigation bar:

Create a responsive navigation bar, including:
- Logo
- Home, Products, About Us, Contact
- Mobile hamburger menu

Algorithmic Art (algorithmic-art):

Create an animation with particle system, including:
- 1000 particles
- Random colors
- Mouse interaction

Canvas Design (canvas-design):

Design an event poster:
- Theme: Spring Sale
- Size: A4
- Include title, date, QR code

üõ†Ô∏è Development Skills

Web Testing (webapp-testing):

Test login functionality on localhost:3000:
1. Open page
2. Enter username and password
3. Click login button
4. Take screenshot and save

MCP Builder (mcp-builder):

Create an MCP server connecting to GitHub API, functions:
- Get repository list
- Create Issue
- View Pull Request

4.3 Skills Usage Tips

Tip 1: Provide Detailed Information

Poor Example:

Create a document
  • Too vague
  • Claude doesn’t know what content to create

Good Example:

Create a Word document, filename report.docx, including:
- Title: Project Report
- Three chapters: Background, Solution, Conclusion
- Each chapter contains 2-3 paragraphs
- Save to current directory
  • Clear and specific
  • Claude knows exactly what to do

Tip 2: Operate Step by Step

For complex tasks, proceed step by step:

Step 1: First help me check what tables are in the database
(wait for results)
Step 2: Query the structure of users table
(wait for results)
Step 3: Export users table as CSV

Why step by step?

  • Each step can confirm results
  • Easy to locate problems when errors occur
  • Can adjust next step based on results

Tip 3: Check What Skills Can Do 

What functions does docx skill have?
What can pdf skill do?
What operations does mysql-manager support?

Claude will list all functions of that skill.

Tip 4: Provide Examples

If you have reference styles:

Create a document similar to example.docx, but change content to...

Tip 5: Specify Output Location 

Create document and save to desktop
Export data to D:/exports/ directory

4.4 Common Usage Scenarios

Scenario 1: Daily Office Work

Requirement: Write weekly work reports

Using Skills:

Use docx skill to create this week's work report:
- Title: Week X Work Report
- Completed work this week (list)
- Next week's plans (list)
- Encountered problems

Scenario 2: Data Processing

Requirement: Process Excel data

Using Skills:

Use xlsx skill:
1. Read sales.xlsx
2. Filter records with amount greater than 1000
3. Sort by date
4. Export as new file

Scenario 3: Web Development

Requirement: Quickly create page prototypes

Using Skills:

Use frontend-design skill to create:
- A product display page
- Including image carousel
- Product card grid
- Responsive layout

Scenario 4: Database Management

Requirement: Regular database backups

Using Skills:

Use mysql-manager skill:
1. Backup production database
2. Save to /backups/ directory
3. Filename includes date

Chapter 6: Practical Case - MySQL Database Management Skill

This chapter will teach you how to create a powerful MySQL database management Skill through a complete practical case.

6.1 Requirements Analysis

Goal: Create a Skill to manage MySQL databases

Functional Requirements:

  1. Database management (create, delete, list)
  2. Table management (create, delete, view structure)
  3. Data querying (SELECT, statistics)
  4. Data operations (insert, update, delete)
  5. Import/export (CSV, JSON, SQL)
  6. Backup and recovery
  7. User management
  8. Performance analysis

Technology Selection:

  • Node.js + mysql2 library
  • Configuration file stores connection information
  • Command-line tool implements various operations

6.2 Creating Skill Structure

Step 1: Create Directory

mkdir -p ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager
cd ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager

Step 2: Initialize npm Project

npm init -y
npm install mysql2

6.3 Creating Configuration File

config.json:

{
 "host": "localhost",
 "port": 3306,
 "user": "root",
 "password": "root",
 "database": "",
 "charset": "utf8mb4",
 "connectionLimit": 10,
 "connectTimeout": 10000,
 "backupPath": "~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager/backups"
}

Configuration Explanation:

  • host: Database server address
  • port: Port number (default 3306)
  • user: Database username
  • password: Database password
  • database: Default database (can be empty)
  • backupPath: Backup file storage path

Security Note:

# Set configuration file permissions (owner read/write only)
chmod 600 config.json

6.4 Creating Core Tool Script

mysql-tool.js (Core functionality implementation):

#!/usr/bin/env node

const mysql = require('mysql2/promise');
const fs = require('fs').promises;
const path = require('path');

// Load configuration
async function loadConfig() {
 const configPath = path.join(__dirname, 'config.json');
 const configData = await fs.readFile(configPath, 'utf8');
 return JSON.parse(configData);
}

// Create database connection
async function createConnection(dbName = null) {
 const config = await loadConfig();
 if (dbName) {
 config.database = dbName;
 }
 return await mysql.createConnection(config);
}

// List all databases
async function listDatabases() {
 const conn = await createConnection();
 const [rows] = await conn.execute('SHOW DATABASES');
 await conn.end();
 return rows.map(row => row.Database);
}

// List all tables
async function listTables(dbName) {
 const conn = await createConnection(dbName);
 const [rows] = await conn.execute('SHOW TABLES');
 await conn.end();
 return rows.map(row => Object.values(row)[0]);
}

// Query data
async function selectAll(dbName, tableName, limit = 100) {
 const conn = await createConnection(dbName);
 const [rows] = await conn.execute(
 `SELECT * FROM \`${tableName}\` LIMIT ?`,
 [limit]
 );
 await conn.end();
 return rows;
}

// Main function
async function main() {
 const args = process.argv.slice(2);
 const command = args[0];

 try {
 let result;

 switch (command) {
 case 'list-databases':
 result = await listDatabases();
 break;
 case 'list-tables':
 result = await listTables(args[1]);
 break;
 case 'select-all':
 result = await selectAll(args[1], args[2], parseInt(args[3] || 100));
 break;
 default:
 console.error('Unknown command:', command);
 process.exit(1);
 }

 console.log(JSON.stringify(result, null, 2));
 } catch (error) {
 console.error('Error:', error.message);
 process.exit(1);
 }
}

if (require.main === module) {
 main();
}

Set Execution Permissions:

chmod +x mysql-tool.js

6.5 Creating SKILL.md 

---
name: mysql-manager
description: Comprehensive MySQL database management tool. Supports connecting to databases, executing queries, data import/export, backup/restore, table structure management, etc. Requires configuration of database connection information before use.
---

# MySQL Database Management Skill

This skill provides comprehensive MySQL database operation functions.

## Configuration

Database connection information is stored in `~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager/config.json`.

Default configuration:
```json
{
 "host": "localhost",
 "port": 3306,
 "user": "root",
 "password": "root"
}

Supported Operations

Database Management

  • List all databases
  • Create database
  • Delete database
  • View database size

Table Management

  • List all tables
  • Create table
  • Delete table
  • View table structure

Data Query

  • SELECT queries
  • Conditional queries
  • Statistical queries

Data Operations

  • Insert data
  • Update data
  • Delete data

Import/Export

  • Export to CSV
  • Export to JSON
  • Export to SQL
  • Import from SQL

Backup and Recovery

  • Backup database
  • Restore database

Usage Examples 

Use mysql-manager to list all databases
Use mysql-manager to query data from users table
Use mysql-manager to backup mydb database

Security Considerations

  1. Configuration file contains sensitive information, ensure permissions are set correctly
  2. Use read-only users for queries in production environments
  3. Confirm before deletion operations
  4. Regularly backup important data

### 6.7 Testing the Skill
**Step 1: Test Connection**
```bash

node mysql-tool.js list-databases

Expected Output:

[
 "information_schema",

6.8 Extending Functions

Adding More Commands:

  1. Create Database:
async function createDatabase(dbName) {
 const conn = await createConnection();
 await conn.execute(`CREATE DATABASE IF NOT EXISTS \`${dbName}\``);
 await conn.end();
 return `Database ${dbName} created successfully`;
}
  1. Export to CSV:
async function exportToCSV(dbName, tableName, outputPath) {
 const conn = await createConnection(dbName);
 const [rows] = await conn.execute(`SELECT * FROM \`${tableName}\``);
 await conn.end();

 const headers = Object.keys(rows[0]).join(',');
 const csvRows = rows.map(row =>
 Object.values(row).map(val =>
 typeof val === 'string' ? `"${val}"` : val
 ).join(',')
 );

 const csv = [headers, ...csvRows].join('\n');
 await fs.writeFile(outputPath, csv, 'utf8');

 return `Export successful: ${outputPath}`;
}
  1. Backup Database:
async function backupDatabase(dbName, outputPath) {
 const cmd = `mysqldump -u ${config.user} -p${config.password} ${dbName} > "${outputPath}"`;
 await execPromise(cmd);
 return `Backup successful: ${outputPath}`;
}

Through this practical case, you learned:

  1. ‚úÖ How to plan Skill functions

Chapter 7: Common Problems and Solutions

7.1 Installation Issues

Problem 1: Cannot Add Official Marketplace

Error Message:

Failed to add marketplace

Possible Causes:

  • Network connection issues
  • Cannot access GitHub
  • Proxy configuration issues

Solutions:

  1. Check network connection:
ping github.com
  1. Configure Git proxy (if in China):
git config --global http.proxy http://proxy.example.com:8080
git config --global https.proxy https://proxy.example.com:8080
  1. Use VPN or proxy

Problem 2: Skills Don’t Show After Installation

Symptoms:

  • Installation successful but Claude doesn’t see skills
  • Asking “What skills do you have?” shows nothing

Solutions:

  1. Restart Claude Code (most common cause):
# Exit
exit

# Restart
claude-code
  1. Check Installation Location:
ls ~/.claude/plugins/cache/
  1. Reinstall:
/plugin uninstall example-skills
/plugin install example-skills@anthropic-agent-skills

Problem 3: Dependency Installation Failed

Error Message:

npm ERR! Cannot find module 'mysql2'

Solutions:

  1. Enter skill directory:
cd ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager
  1. Install dependencies:
npm install mysql2
  1. If still failing, clear cache:
npm cache clean --force
npm install

7.2 Usage Issues

Problem 4: Skill Execution Failed

Error Message:

Error: Command failed

Troubleshooting Steps:

  1. Check if command is correct:
# Manually test command
cd ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager
node mysql-tool.js list-databases

  1. View error details: Claude usually shows detailed error information

  2. Check permissions:

# Ensure script has execution permissions
chmod +x mysql-tool.js
  1. Check configuration file:
# Validate JSON format
cat config.json | python -m json.tool

Problem 5: Claude Chose Wrong Skill

Symptoms:

  • You want to use skill A, but Claude used skill B

Solutions:

  1. Explicitly specify skill:
Use docx skill to create document (instead of "create document")
  1. Provide more detailed description:
Use mysql-manager skill to query database
  1. Check SKILL.md description: Ensure description is clear and won’t confuse with other skills

Problem 6: Configuration File Not Found

Error Message:

Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory

Solutions:

  1. Check if file exists:
ls ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager/config.json
  1. Check path correctness: Use absolute path in script:
const configPath = path.join(__dirname, 'config.json');
  1. Create configuration file:
cd ~/.claude/skills/mysql-manager
cat > config.json << EOF
{
 "host": "localhost",
 "port": 3306
}
EOF

7.3 Database Issues

Problem 7: Cannot Connect to Database

Error Messages:

Error: connect ECONNREFUSED
Error: Access denied for user

Solutions:

  1. Check if MySQL service is running:
# Windows
sc query MySQL

# Mac
brew services list | grep mysql

# Linux
systemctl status mysql
  1. Check connection information:
# Test connection
mysql -h localhost -u root -p
  1. Check firewall:
# Linux
sudo ufw status

# Windows
netsh advfirewall show allprofiles
  1. Check user permissions:
-- Execute in MySQL
SHOW GRANTS FOR 'root'@'localhost';

Problem 8: Backup Failed

Error Message:

mysqldump: command not found

Solutions:

  1. Install MySQL client tools:
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt-get install mysql-client

# Mac
brew install mysql-client

# Windows
# Download MySQL Installer
  1. Add to PATH (Windows):
Add C:\Program Files\MySQL\MySQL Server 8.0\bin to system PATH
  1. Use full path:
const mysqldumpPath = 'C:\\Program Files\\MySQL\\MySQL Server 8.0\\bin\\mysqldump.exe';

7.4 Performance Issues

Problem 9: Queries Are Slow

Symptoms:

  • Querying large tables responds slowly
  • Claude takes long time to respond

Solutions:

  1. Limit query count:
// Default limit 100 rows
async function selectAll(dbName, tableName, limit = 100) {
 // ...
}
  1. Add indexes:
CREATE INDEX idx_name ON users(name);
  1. Use pagination:
async function selectPage(dbName, tableName, page, pageSize) {
 const offset = (page - 1) * pageSize;
 const [rows] = await conn.execute(
 `SELECT * FROM \`${tableName}\` LIMIT ? OFFSET ?`,
 [pageSize, offset]
 );
 return rows;
}

Problem 10: High Memory Usage

Symptoms:

  • Node.js process occupies large memory
  • System becomes slow

Solutions:

  1. Use streaming processing:
const stream = conn.query(`SELECT * FROM large_table`).stream();
stream.on('data', (row) => {
 // Process each row
});
  1. Close connections promptly:
try {
 // Operations
} finally {
 await conn.end();
}
  1. Limit connection pool size:
{
 "connectionLimit": 5
}

7.5 Document Issues

Problem 11: Word Document Creation Failed

Error Message:

Cannot find module 'docx'

Solutions:

  1. Install docx globally:
npm install -g docx
  1. Or install in project:
cd /path/to/project
npm install docx

Problem 12: PDF Processing Failed

Error Message:

pdftoppm: command not found

Solutions:

  1. Install Poppler:
# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt-get install poppler-utils

# Mac
brew install poppler

# Windows
# Download Poppler for Windows

7.6 Debugging Tips

Tip 1: Enable Detailed Logging

Add logging in script:

console.log('Starting execution:', command);
console.log('Parameters:', args);
console.log('Configuration:', config);

Tip 2: Use Debug Mode
